title-group.article-title: Kalihiacyloxyamides A-H, α-acyloxy amide substituted kalihinane diterpenes isolated from the sponge Acanthella cavernosa collected in the South China Sea

kwd.tp:taxon-name: Stylissa cf. massa ( Chanthathamrongsiri et al., 2012 )

Kalihiacyloxyamides A-H , α -acyloxy amide substituted kalihinane diterpenes isolated from the sponge

collected in the South China Sea

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Kalihinane diterpenes Configuration determination Cytotoxicity
ABSTRACT

Eight unreported α -acyloxy amide substituted kalihinane diterpenes, named kalihiacyloxyamides A-H were isolated from the South China Sea sponge
Acanthella cavernosa
. The planar structures and absolute configurations were elucidated by detailed 1D and 2D NMR experiments along with HRESIMS analysis, single crystal X-ray diffraction and CD spectroscopic analysis. Two compounds showed significant cytotoxicity against K562 cell line with IC 50 values of 6.4 and 6.3 μM, while two other compounds displayed moderate cytotoxicity against MDA- MB-231 with IC 50 values of 7.3 and 7.9 μM.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
In our previous study, we had reported the isolation of seven unreported diterpenes kalihioxepanes A-G from the sponge
Acanthella cavernosa Dendy (Dictyonellidae)
collected in 2012 (
). In the further course of our project on discovering bioactive compounds from the marine sponges of the genus
Acanthella
, eight unreported α -acyloxy amide substituted kalihinane diterpenes, named kalihiacyloxyamides A-H (
1–8
) ( Fig. 1 ) were isolated from
A. cavernosa
collected off Xisha islands in the South China Sea in 2018. Here we describe the isolation, structural elucidation and bioactivity assays.

sec.title: 2.1. Structure elucidation
sec.p: Kalihiacyloxyamide A ( 1 ) was isolated as a colorless bulk crystal (MeOH). A molecular formula of C 25 H 41 ClN 2 O 4 was established by the
a Measured in CDCl.
3 b Measured in CD OD.

According to literature (
), the CD spectra of kalihinols is mainly determined by the C-4 and C-5 configuration of them. Thus, the experimental ECD spectra match of 2 with 1 ( Fig. 5 ) assign the absolute configurations of 2 as 1 S , 4 R , 5 R , 6 S , 7 S , 10 S , 11 R , 14 R .

The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 3 and 1 were comparable except for a marked difference in the substituent unit that 3 has one more iso-amyl ester unit than 1 ( Tables 1 and 3 ). The COSY correlations of H 2 -6’/H- 7’/(H 3 -8 ′ and H 3 -9 ′ ) and the HMBC correlations of (H-7 ′ and H 2 -6 ′ )/C-5 ′ , C-8 ′ and C-9 ′ supported the assignment of kalihiacyloxyamide C as 3 ( Fig. 2 ). The location of the iso-amyl ester unit was assigned to be at C-2 ′ by single crystal X-ray diffraction using Cu K α radiation ( Fig. 4 ), and the absolute structure of kalihiacyloxyamide C ( 3 ) was unambiguously determined to be 1 S , 4 R , 5 R , 6 S , 7 S , 10 S , 11 R , and 14 S .

Kalihiacyloxyamide G ( 7 ) was isolated as colorless needles (MeOH), and given a C 30 H 50 N 2 O 5 molecular formula based on the HRESIMS (m/z 519.3782 [M + H] + ). The NMR spectra of 7 ( Tables 2 and 4 ) revealed the presence of one formamide group ( δ C 160.3) (
), one amide carbon ( δ C 172.6), an ester group carbon ( δ C 171.2), nine methyls [ δ H 0.98 (6H, d, J =6.4 Hz), 1.15 (3H, s), 1.31 (3H, s), 1.36 (3H, s), 1.53 (3H, s), 1.55 (3H, s), 1.57 (3H, s), and 1.61 (3H, s)], one trisubstituted double bond [ δ H 5.70 (1H, brs), δ C 127.5/ δ C 130.8], an oxymethine [ δ H 3.89 (1H, m)/ δ C 83.8], and two oxygenated non-protonated carbons ( δ C 85.9 and 81.3). The COSY correlations of H 2 -9/H 2 -8/H-7/H-6/H-1/H 2 -2/H 2 -3 and H-5/H-6, associated with the HMBC correlations of H 3 -19/C-3, C-4, and C-5, H 3 -20/C-1, C-10, and C-9, H-5/C-1, C-3, C-6 and C-7, and CHO/C-10 indicated the presence of a decalin moiety ( Fig. 2 ). A tetrahydrofuran ring, attached to the decalin ring at C-7, was established by carbon resonances at δ C 85.9 (C-11) and 83.8 (C-14), COSY correlations of H 2 -12/H 2 -13/H-14, HMBC correlations of H 3 -18/C-7, C-11, and C-12 and geminal methyls (H 3 -16 and H 3 -17)/C-14 and C-15, and NOESY correlation between H 3 -18 and H-14. A α -acyloxy amide group (Substituent b) was confirmed by HMBC

and 55.7 (C-15) in 7 were replaced by those at δ C 56.0 (C-10) and 54.7 (C-15) in 8 , respectively, indicating the position of the isonitrile and α -acyloxy amide groups (Substituent b) had been interchanged in 8 from 7 . The absolute configuration of 8 was unambiguously determined as 1 R , 6 S , 7 S , 10 S , 11 R , and 14 S by single crystal X-ray diffraction using Cu K α radiation ( Fig. 4 ).
a Data for s- trans isomer.
b Data
for s- cis isomer.

correlations of the geminal methyls (H 3 -3 ′ and H 3 -4 ′ )/C-1 ′ and C-2 ′ , the geminal methyls (H 3 -8 ′ and H 3 -9 ′ )/C-7 ′ and C-6 ′ , H 2 -6’/C-5 ′ , C-7 ′ , C-8 ′ and C-9 ′ and the COSY correlations of H 2 -6’/H-7’/H 3 -8 ′ and H 3 -9 ′ , and attached at C-15 ( δ C 55.7) on the basis of corresponding HMBC correlation from 15-NH to C-15, C-16 and C-1’. Fortunately, we obtained the colorless needles of
7 in
methanol, and the absolute structure of 7 was unambiguously determined to be 1 R , 6 S , 7 S , 10 S , 11 R , and 14 S by single crystal X-ray diffraction using Cu K α radiation ( Fig. 4 ).
Compound 8 possessed the same skeleton as 7 based on the 1D and 2D NMR data ( Tables 2 and 4 ). The carbon resonances at δ C 56.9 (C-10)

sec.title: 2.2. Bioactivity evaluation
3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In conclusion, we firstly reported eight unreported α -acyloxy amide substituted kalihinane type diterpenoids Kalihiacyloxyamides A-H ( 1–8 ) from the South China Sea sponge
A. cavernosa .
The structures including absolute configurations were elucidated by combined methods such as 1D and 2D NMR experiments, HRESIMS analysis, single crystal X-ray diffraction, and some reported rules. Compounds 3 , 5 , and 8 exhibited significant cytotoxity against K562 and MDA-MB-231 cell lines with IC 50 values ranging from 6.3 to 12.5 μM
.

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: NMR spectra were measured by Bruker ASCEND TM 400 MHz, Bruker AVANCE III 500 spectrometers and JEOL JNMECP 600. HRESIMS spectra were measured on a Micro-mass Q-Tof Ultima GLOBAL GAA076 LC mass spectrometer. Optical rotations were recorded on a Jasco P-1020 digital polarimeter. UV and CD spectra were taken on a Jasco J-810 spectropolarimeter. X-ray data were obtained by a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer using graphite monochromated Cu-K α radiation. Column chromatography (CC) was performed with silica gel (100–400 mesh, Qingdao Marine Chemical Inc., Qingdao, P. R. China ), ODS silica gel (50 μm, Merck). HPLC was performed on a Waters 2695/ 2998 instrument with DAD detector, equipped with an analytic reversed-phased column (ZORBAX 80 A Extend-C18, 250 × 4.6 mm , 5 μm, 1.0 mL/min). Semi-preparative HPLC used an ODS column [YMC- Pack ODS-A, 10 × 250 mm , 5 μm, 1.5 mL/min].

sec.title: 4.2. Sponge material
sec.p:
The marine sponge
Acanthella cavernosa Dendy (Dictyonellidae)
was collected off Xisha islands in the South China
Sea (
111 ◦ 42 ′ E
,
16 ◦ 33 ′ N
) at a depth of
20 m
on
July 3rd, 2018
and was identified by Nicole J. de Voogd , National Museum of Natural History , The Netherlands. A voucher sample (No. XS-2018-18) was deposited at Key Laboratory of Marine Drugs , Chinese Ministry of Education , School of Medicine and Pharmacy, Ocean University of China, China
.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: Marine sponge ( 5.5 kg , wet weight) was homogenized and extracted with MeOH (20 Lx4), and then the concentrated residue ( 204 g ) was dissolved in MeOH (1 L) to remove salts. The MeOH solution was evaporated under vacuum to yield a crude extract ( 82 g ). The crude extract was suspended in H 2 O (1 L), which was then extracted with EtOAc (1 L) for three times to yield the EtOAc soluble extract ( 32 g ). The extract was fractionated by silica gel CC and eluted using petroleum ether-acetone (20:1, 10:1, 5:1, 3:1, 1:1, acetone, v/v) and CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (10:1, 5:1, 3:1, 1:1, MeOH, v/v) to obtain eleven fractions (Ac.1-Ac.11). Ac.8 ( 0.64 g ) was separated on silica gel CC eluting with petroleum ether-acetone (8:1 and 5:1, v/v) to give subfractions Ac.8.1-Ac.8.5. Ac.8.2 ( 249 mg ) was separated by MPLC (C-18 ODS) with MeOH/H 2 O (85:15, v/v) to yield seven subfractions (Ac.8.2.1 to Ac.8.2.7). Ac.8.2.3 ( 15.4 mg ) was fractionated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (65:35, v/v) to obtain compound 3 ( 12.3 mg , tR =56 min). Ac.9 ( 2.76 g ) was fractionated on silica gel CC eluting with petroleum ether-acetone (10:1 and 5:1, v/v) to give subfractions Ac.9.1-Ac.9.4. Ac.9.2 ( 1.24 g ) was separated by MPLC (C-18 ODS) with MeOH/H 2 O (75:25, v/v) to yield five subfractions (Ac.9.2.1 to Ac.9.2.5). Ac.9.2.2 ( 287 mg ) was fractionated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (65:35, v/v) to obtain compound 4 ( 55 mg , tR = 38 min). Ac.9.2.3 ( 168 mg ) was fractionated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (65:35, v/v) to yield three subfractions (Ac.9.2.3.1 to Ac.9.2.3.3). Ac.9.2.3.3 ( 19.7 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (55:45, v/v) to obtain compounds 8 ( 9 mg , tR = 95 min) and 5 ( 5.3 mg , tR = 105 min). Ac.10 ( 1.75 g ) was separated on silica gel CC eluting with petroleum ether-acetone (6:1, v/ v) to give subfractions Ac.10.1-Ac.10.5. Ac.10.3 ( 583 mg ) was separated by MPLC (C-18 ODS) with MeOH/H 2 O (75:25, v/v) to yield five subfractions (Ac.10.3.1 to Ac.10.3.5). Ac.10.3.4 ( 129 mg ) was fractionated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (65:35, v/v) to obtain compound 6 ( 3.7 mg , tR = 33 min). Ac.10.3.5 ( 75.8 mg ) was fractionated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (55:45, v/v) to obtain compound 7 ( 3.2 mg , tR = 65 min). Ac.11 ( 1.93 g ) was fractionated on silica gel CC eluting with petroleum ether-acetone (5:1, v/v) to give subfractions Ac.11.1-Ac.11.7. Ac.11.6 ( 1.08 g ) was separated by MPLC (C-18 ODS) with MeOH/H 2 O (70:30, v/v) to yield five subfractions (Ac.11.6.1 to Ac.11.6.5). Ac.11.6.2 ( 110 mg ) was fractionated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (50:50, v/v) to obtain compound 1 ( 48 mg , tR = 28 min). Ac.11.6.1 ( 166 mg ) was fractionated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (50:50, v/v) to yield six subfractions (Ac.11.6.1.1 to Ac.11.6.1.6). Ac.11.6.1.4 ( 14.8 mg ) was purified by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN/H 2 O (40:60, v/v) to obtain compound 2 ( 11.8 mg , tR =46 min).

sec.title: 4.3.1. Kalihiacyloxyamide A (1)
sec.p: Colorless bulk crystal; [ α ]25 D +3.7 ( c 0.16, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 205 (3.04); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 469.2817 [M +H] + (calcd for C 25 H 35 42 ClN 2 O 4 , 469.2828).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Kalihiacyloxyamide B (2)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25 D +7.6 ( c 0.72, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 203 (3.34); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 469.2822 [M +H] + (calcd for C 25 H 35 42 ClN 2 O 4 , 469.2828).

sec.title: 4.3.3. Kalihiacyloxyamide C (3)
sec.p: Colorless bulk crystal; [ α ]25 D +7.0 ( c 0.73, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 205 (3.44); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 553.3403 [M +H] + (calcd for C 30 H 35 50 ClN 2 O 5 , 553.3403).

sec.title: 4.3.4. Kalihiacyloxyamide D (4)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25 D +4.3 ( c 1.20, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 203 (3.42); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 1 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 553.3401 [M +H] + (calcd for C 30 H 50 35 ClN 2 O 5 , 553.3414).
a Measured at 100 MHz.
b Measured at 125 MHz.
ADM: doxorubicin (positive control); ND: Not Do.

sec.title: 4.3.5. Kalihiacyloxyamide E (5)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25 D +6.2 ( c 0.53, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 204 (3.64); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 609.3067 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 33 H 35 47 ClN 2 O 5 Na, 609.3066).

sec.title: 4.3.6. Kalihiacyloxyamide F (6)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25 D +3.7 ( c 0.16, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 209 (3.53); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 2 and 3 ; HRESIMS m/z 609.3065 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 33 H 47 35 ClN 2 O 5 Na, 609.3066).

sec.title: 4.3.7. Kalihiacyloxyamide G (7)
sec.p: Colorless needles; [ α ]25 D 14.8 ( c 0.15, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 201 (3.36); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 2 and 4 ; HRESIMS m/ z 519.3782 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 51 N 2 O 5 , 519.3792).

sec.title: 4.3.8. Kalihiacyloxyamide H (8)
sec.p: Colorless needles; [ α ]25 D 17.2 ( c 0.53, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 200 (3.49); 1 H and 13 C NMR data see Tables 2 and 4 ; HRESIMS m/ z 519.3787 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 51 N 2 O 5 , 519.3792).

sec.title: 4.4. X-ray diffraction data analysis
sec.p:
Kalihiacyloxyamide A ( 1 ) was obtained colorless crystal from MeOH using the vapor diffusion method. The orthorhombic crystal (0.20 × 0.15 × 0.10) was measured on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer with Cu-K α radiation at 150 K. Crystal data of 1 : empirical formula C 25 H 41 ClN 2 O 4 , M =469.05; space group P 212121 , unit cell dimensions a = 6.7943 (2) Å, b = 8.5259 (2) Å, c = 44.4580 (11) Å, α = β = γ = 90.00 ◦ , V = 2575.34 (12) Å 3 , Z = 4, Dcalcd = 1.210 g cm 3 , μ = 1.565 mm 1 , F (000) =1016.0; a total of 16,312 reflections were collected in the range of 3.974 ◦ < 2
θ <
148.884 ◦ , of which 5081 independent reflections [ Rint =0.0336, Rsigma =0.0380] were used for the analysis. The final R indexes [all data] gave R 1 =0.0301, wR 2 =0.0778 and the Flack parameter = 0.021 (5). Crystallographic data of 1 have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (Deposition number: CCDC 2155533). The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc. cam.ac.uk/products/csd/request.

Kalihiacyloxyamide C ( 3 ) was obtained colorless crystal from MeOH using the vapor diffusion method. The triclinic crystal (0.20 × 0.15 × 0.10) was measured on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer with Cu-K α radiation at 150 K. Crystal data of 3 : empirical formula C 30 H 49 ClN 2 O 5 , M =553.16; space group P1, unit cell dimensions a =12.4782 (12) Å, b =16.3643 (16) Å, c =17.7453 (17) Å, α =102.769 (6) ◦ , β =99.716 (6) ◦ , γ =101.120 (6) ◦ , V =3381.9 (6) Å 3 , Z =4, Dcalcd = 1.086 g cm 3 , μ = 1.282 mm 1 , F (000) = 1200.0; a total of 28,530 reflections were collected in the range of 5.704 ◦ < 2
θ <
136.49 ◦ , of which 21,016 independent reflections [ Rint =0.0791, Rsigma =0.0845] were used for the analysis. The final R indexes [all data] gave R 1 =0.0832, wR 2 =0.1482 and the Flack parameter =0.024 (12). Crystallographic data of 3 have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (Deposition number: CCDC 2155535). The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/products/csd/request.

Kalihiacyloxyamide G ( 7 ) was obtained colorless crystal from MeOH using the vapor diffusion method. The orthorhombic crystal (0.20 × 0.15 × 0.12) was measured on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer with Cu-K α radiation at 150 K. Crystal data of 7 : empirical formula C 30 H 50 N 2 O 5 , M =518.72; space group P 212121 , unit cell dimensions a = 10.6615 (5) Å, b = 15.8192 (8) Å, c = 18.2491 (10) Å, α = β = γ = 90.00 ◦ , V = 3077.8 (3) Å 3 , Z = 4, Dcalcd = 1.119 g cm 3 , μ = 0.597 mm 1 , F (000) =1136.0; a total of 14,825 reflections were collected in the range of 9.692 ◦ < 2
θ <
144.576 ◦ , of which 5868 independent reflections [ Rint =0.0504, Rsigma =0.0576] were used for the analysis. The final R indexes [all data] gave R 1 =0.0556, wR 2 =0.1229 and the Flack parameter = 0.07 (13). Crystallographic data of 7 have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (Deposition number: CCDC 2155536). The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc. cam.ac.uk/products/csd/request.

Kalihiacyloxyamide H ( 8 ) was obtained colorless crystal from MeOH using the vapor diffusion method. The monoclinic crystal (0.20 × 0.15 × 0.10) was measured on a Bruker APEX-II CCD diffractometer with Cu- K α radiation at 150 K. Crystal data of 8 : empirical formula C 30 H 50 N 2 O 5 , M =518.72; space group P 21 , unit cell dimensions a =5.8338 (2) Å, b = 8.8996 (2) Å, c =28.4762 (8) Å, α = γ =90.00 ◦ , β =95.173 (2) ◦ , V = 1472.42 (7) Å 3 , Z =2, Dcalcd = 1.170 g cm 3 , μ = 0.624 mm 1 , F (000) = 568.0; a total of 13,245 reflections were collected in the range of 6.232 ◦ < 2
θ <
148.992 ◦ , of which 5253 independent reflections [ Rint = 0.0522, Rsigma =0.0548] were used for the analysis. The final R indexes [all data] gave R 1 = 0.0499, wR 2 = 0.1012 and the Flack parameter =

0.01 (14). Crystallographic data of 8 have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (Deposition number: CCDC 2155537). The data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/products/csd/request.

sec.title: 4.5. Cytotoxicity assay
sec.p: Cytotoxic activities of 1–8 were evaluated using K562 (human leukemia cell lines) by the MTT method and L-02 (human normal hepatocyte cell lines), MDA-MB-231 (human breast cancer cell lines), ASPC-1 (human pancreatic cancer cell lines) and H69AR (human lung carcinoma cell lines) using the SRB method, with doxorubicin as positive control.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Data availability
No data was used for the research described in the article.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. U2006204, 41776136, 2181101213, 81991522, and 41876161). Special thanks are given to Dr. Jing Li (School of Medicine and Pharmacy, Ocean University of China ) for cytotoxic activity tests.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2022.113512.
